description: В нашем докладе мы расскажем наш опыт разработки 10+ проектов, используя Kotlin Multiplatform в связке с Kotlin/Native, расскажем из каких блоков и модулей состоит архитектура мультиплатформенных проектов, какие сложности и преимущества даёт mpp. В докладе затронем следующие разделы архитектуры в shared library: - шаблонизацию UI - работу с сетью - стандартизацию функционала - разделение на "универсальные" и "проектнозависимые" фичи Затронем также нюансы погружений iOS- и Anroid-специалистов в mpp.

speaker: Claudia Luque Fernández
title: Droidcon
subject: Kotlin DSL For Android Projects
description: Let´s face it, Groovy is ok, but Kotlin is irresistible. During this talk you are going to learn how easy it is to migrate your Android project to Kotlin DSL and find on the way some tips to boost the gradle files reusability.

speaker: Márton Braun
title: Droidcon
subject: Idio~~ma~~tic Kotlin
description: "Idiomatic" is a word often used by Kotlin experts to describe elegant patterns or solutions that make excellent use of Kotlin’s features. In this session you will discover how to abuse Kotlin language features to take shortcuts, create tricky solutions, achieve exciting syntax, or confuse others who dare enter your codebase.

speaker: Marcin Moskala
title: Droidcon
subject: Workshop: Understanding Kotlin Coroutines
description:
Kotlin Coroutines is a powerful tool. Well implemented concept of suspendable computation... It is a dream of many theoretics of concurrent programming for a long time. But how is it possible? How do Kotlin coroutines really work? Why are they important? What do they introduce? And finally, how you can use them in your project?

In this workshop, Marcin will share how to use Kotlin Coroutines and what makes them so special and so efficient. You will also explore if they are an alternative to RxJava.

speaker: Vipul Shah
title: Mobilization
subject: Kotlin/Native and Multiplatform Development
description: This workshop will introduced you to Kotlin/Native and build a Kotlin Multiplatform app that runs on both iOS and Android using shared Kotlin code. We will cover following topics in this workshop Introduction to Kotlin/Native and Multiplatform Your First Kotlin/Native Program Creating a Multiplatform Project Shared Library from Android & iOS Networking & Concurrency using Ktor & Coroutines Designing Android & iOS user interface Debugging multiplatform Project Drawbacks

speaker: Marcin Moskala
title: Mobilization
subject: Kotlin Not-to-Do List - What we should avoid doing in Kotlin
description: Kotlin gives us a lot of possibilities, but with every power comes responsibility. What should we avoid doing in Kotlin? What are Kotlin internal contracts in terms of different features and functions? What is dangerous and should be avoided? How to code responsively?

speaker: Marcin Moskala
title: Mobilization
subject: Kotlin Coroutines
description: The workshop covers asynchronous programming in Kotlin using coroutines. It covers both build-in support for coroutines and dives deeper into kotlinx.coroutines library.

speaker: Michael Hunger
title: GOTO
subject: Not your Father's Java - Building a GraphQL Server with Kotlin and graphql-java
description: Building APIs in Java is not that exciting. That changes if you throw GraphQL and Kotlin into the mix. The great library and powerful, concise language make it easy to build a GraphQL server in a few lines of code. With co-routines and lambdas as a glue, you get a neat, scalable backend. As an icing on the cake we will also look into using Kotlins multiplatform capabilities to run our code as Javascript or Native servers.

speaker: Filip Babic
title: Droidcon
subject: Deep diving into the Kotlin Coroutines API
description:
“Have you been learning Kotlin Coroutines by trial and error? Do you need a change of pace and environment or just a guide which doesn’t baffle you with the sheer amounts of computer science terms, which coroutines are built upon?

Look no more! In this session, we’ll go over the majority of the Kotlin Coroutines API, with the emphasis on explaining how each component works, which principles and elements are used behind the scenes, and how you can utilize Coroutines in your code, without burning out due to all the theory that is the foundation of computing and multi-threading.”

speaker: Join Corneil
title: Melbourne Java & JVM Users Group
subject: Kotlin DSL for Finite State Machines (FSM)
description:
The typical Software Developer's day is looking for a solution to a complex (and even simple) problem in google. And more often than not, Baeldung blog has the solution already to those problems. Keen on meeting one of the brains behind this blog?

Join Corneil on the journey of developing a Kotlin Multiplatform DSL for Finite State Machines (FSM). During the presentation, the need and use of finite state machines is discussed, and how to create a DSL in Kotlin for configuring an FSM.

speaker: Juan Pablo Villa
title: Kotlin CDMX User Group
subject: Kotlin 101 - Cómo empezar desde 0 con Kotlin
description: Cómo empezar desde 0 con Kotlin. En esta charla, por Juan Pablo Villa, reconocido desarrollador Kotlin, se darán algunos tips de cómo hacer lo que hacías con Java, en Kotlin. Si aún no decides dar el paso o no sabes por dónde empezar, esta plática es para ti.

speaker: Paweł Marks
title: Kraków Kotlin User Group
subject: Free workshops: Kotlin- the deeper look
description: Follow up workshop to the introduction to Kotlin. This time concepts such as reified generics or reflection will be introduced. This workshop should also familiarize the attendees with coroutines and few other basic abstractions that are used in asynchronous programming in Kotlin.

speaker: Peter Oost
title: Kotlin User Group Munich - KUG Munich
subject: Jetpack Compose — Declarative UIs for Android

speaker: Maxim Mazin
title: Kotlin User Group Munich - KUG Munich
subject: «Xodus» — schema-less embedded database for Kotlin

speaker: Enrique López Mañas
title: Kotlin User Group Munich - KUG Munich
subject: Diving into coroutines for Android

speaker: Alexander Podkhalyuzin
title: Kraków Kotlin User Group
subject: Kotlin Multiplatform: a trip from JVM to JS
description: Kotlin is a programming language, which is widely known for the Android platform. Kotlin is also used for server-side development. Our team has been actively working on Kotlin multiplatform for a few years, which is mainly tooling for simple sharing code between different backends, including Kotlin/JS. In this talk I’ll show you how to actually share some code between the existing JVM/Android codebase and the client code. Such code sharing is experimental stuff, so we would like to collect as much feedback as possible to implement what we lack in tooling perspective for such a promising technology.As a bonus, we will take a look at a simple full-stack application, which is completely written in Kotlin.

speaker: Paweł Marks
title: Kraków Kotlin User Group
subject: Superpowers for tailoring asynchrony or how to customize your coroutines
description: Kotlin coroutines have gained a lot of traction since their stabilization. They are a lightweight, elegant and convenient solution for most of the asynchronous processing tasks. Using coroutines, developers can write code solving concurrency problems without drowning in the flood of callbacks.Since coroutines were stabilized only a year ago, there is a really good chance that your current project is based on some other library or framework for asynchronous processing. Does it mean that you cannot benefit from elegant, easy to reason code that coroutines bring to the table? In this talk, I am going to show you how you can bring powers of coroutines into your mature and borning framework. Or maybe your case is different and your project is already using lots of ‘async’s and ‘launch’es. Then you will see superpowers you can use to make your asynchronous code more readable and less repetitive.

speaker: Krystian Rybarczyk
title: Kraków Kotlin User Group
subject: Flows – Kotlin’s shot at concurrency
description: Concurrency is and certainly will be one of the biggest challenges we, developers, now face having to squeeze everything out of all the cores our CPUs have. With Kotlin you do not need to struggle with Java’s threads or Scala’s actors. Kotlin has its own concurrency model and I will show you why it is really cool and that it’s worth having a look at. During this presentation we will look into coroutines and see how they facilitate asynchronous programming. We will talk about flows and see how they make writing reactive code a breeze. If flows fit into your domain why not give Kotlin a shot?

speaker: Marcin Moskala
title: Kraków Kotlin User Group
subject: Kotlin Not-to-Do List – What we should avoid doing in Kotlin
description: Kotlin gives us a lot of possibilities, but with every power comes responsibility. What should we avoid doing in Kotlin? What are Kotlin internal contracts in terms of different features and functions? What is dangerous and should be avoided? How to code responsively?

speaker: Javier Olan
title: Mérida Kotlin User Group
subject: De Java Callbacks a Kotlin Lambdas
description:
Para aquellos usuarios del mundo de java que siempre han tenido la inquietud de que existe una forma de mejorar los tan famosos y tediosos callbacks de Java, ahora con Kotlin y los lambdas llega una presentación mas elegante de como manejar eventos con pocas lineas de código.

es 2019-10-10 2019-10-10 Mérida, Mexico Luis Burgos Mérida Kotlin User Group Extensions for reducing boilerplate https://www.meetup.com/Merida-Kotlin-User-Group/events/265196964/ Kotlin ofrece la capacidad de extender una clase con una nueva funcionalidad sin tener que heredar de la clase o usar patrones de diseño como Decorator mediante las Extensions, con esto podemos reducir la cantidad de código repetido en nuestras clases.

speaker: Mario Guillermo
title: Mérida Kotlin User Group
subject: Standard function run with let also apply
description: Kotlin nos proporciona en su librería estandar 5 funciones cuyo propósito es ejecutar un bloque de código dentro del contexto de un objeto. Estas funcionse son let, run, with, apply y also. Pero, ¿Qué son?, ¿Cuál es la diferencia entre ellas?, ¿Cuándo las utilizo?.

speaker: Victoria Gonda
title: Chicago Kotlin Users Group
subject: Test-Driven Development
description: Test-Driven Development (TDD) is a software development process where you write failing tests before writing the code to make it pass. This can be a common practice in some technology circles, but we’ve seen slow adoption on Android. Because it’s not embedded in the Android culture, it can be hard to learn how to get started with TDD. In this talk, we’ll go over the basics of TDD, how you can apply it at varying levels in an Android architecture, and what steps to take if you’re working with legacy code. You should walk away from this talk with the tools you need to get started exploring practicing TDD on your own.

speaker: Victoria Gonda
title: AndroidListener Chicago
subject: Kotlin + Android: Test-Driven Development & Meta Programming
description:
Meta Programming with Couroutines / Jetpack - Mark will lead us into the internals of his open source project to discuss how he implemented retrofit/moshi with Kotlin

Android: Test-Driven Development - Victoria Gonda will go over the basics of TDD, how you can apply it at varying levels in an Android architecture, and what steps to take if you’re working with legacy code. You should walk away from this talk with the tools you need to get started exploring practicing TDD on your own.

speaker: Donn Felker
title: New York Kotlin Meetup
subject: Building Domain Specific Languages (DSL’s) with Kotlin
description:
Have you ever written a utility or library to help manage some complex code? What about a helper classes to manage some nasty setup of a really awkward library? You're probably sharing your head in agreement "yes, oh yes I've done that."

What if there was a way to create a beautiful API for that nasty code that was easy to use? You're in luck, because it exists, you just need to build a DSL (Domain Specific Language) around said code. Yes, its more work, but in the end it can make your code more readable, manageable and easier to consume. All resulting in a better development experience.

In this session, Donn will show you what a DSL is and how to build one use lambda functions, receivers and more … all in Kotlin. At the end of the talk you should had a good understanding of how to build a DSL so that you can make your teams development experience that much richer.

speaker: Josh Williams
title: New York Kotlin Meetup
subject: To Extend or not to Extend (and other QTNA)
description: When should you create an extension rather than an instance function? When should you create an extension rather than a Util class? Should we even still use Builders? All of these questions have answers that usually are ambiguous at most and usually left up to preference when using Kotlin. I will provide you tips, from my experience, to help make it easier to answer these questions and strengthen your development.

speaker: Tim Fredette
title: Dublin Kotlin User Group
subject: how to convert your app to Kotlin
description: Our first speaker will be Tim Fredette, who will be showing us how to convert your app to Kotlin. Tim was the first engineering hire in Toast, and I think it's safe to say has built more of the platform than anyone else, growing the company from zero customers to tens of thousands of customers in the US.

speaker: Tom Hanley
title: Dublin Kotlin User Group
subject: Migrating to Kotlin - A Step by Step guide
description: Our second speaker will be Tom Hanley, who will be guiding us through migrating your Gradle files to the Gradle Kotlin DSL. Tom is a Java engineer turned passionate Kotliner working in Toast. As well as organising the Dublin Kotlin User Group, he is a regular presenter at meetups on Kotlin, and will be speaking at this years KotlinConf in December

speaker: Anton Spaans
title: Kotlin Office Hours
subject: Kotlin Office Hours at Rocket Insights
description: Kotlin is an open-source programming language developed by JetBrains which has seen an upswell of interest since it's 1.0 release in 2016. It now supports not only JVM but JavaScript and LLVM architectures as well. We will have experts speaking about Kotlin and its use in these various architectures, showing their knowledge and the projects that they are working on.

speaker: Lothar Schulz
title: Kotlin user group Berlin
subject: Continuous Delivery to Kubernetes with jib, skaffold and ktor

speaker: Jean-Michel Fayard
title: Kotlin user group Berlin
subject: Android’s billion dollar mistake `Activity is Context`, and how to fix it with Kotlin

speaker: Eric Ampire
title: Lubumbashi Kotlin User Group
subject: Android programming with Kotlin and Firebase
description: Durant cette session de formation nous allons apprendre à développer une application Android de messagerie instantanée en utilisant les services fournit par Firebase.

speaker: Ryan Simon
title: OC Kotlin Krew
subject: Practical Kotlin Workshop: Coroutines and Flows
description: will be running an interactive workshop on Kotlin Coroutines and Flows.

speaker: Olmo Gallegos
title: Malaga Mobile
subject: Understanding kotlinx.coroutines a little deeper
description: In this talk we will introduce some concepts related to kotlinx.coroutines library, often not included in introductory talks and that are a “must have” for all devs using the library.

speaker: Satyabrata Samal
title: Edureka Masterclass
subject: Kotlin Fundamentals Explained In 90 Minutes (Online Webinar)
description: 1. History Of Kotlin 2. Understanding Kotlin Features & Architecture 3. How To Run A Kotlin Code? 4. Understanding Kotlin Code Basics

speaker: Ryan Fonzi
title: AsturiasHacking
subject: Introducción a Kotlin
description: ¿Tienes ganas de conocer Kotlin y todavía no has tenido tiempo de echarle un vistazo? En esta charla se hará una introducción al lenguaje Kotlin (corriendo sobre JVM) y está orientada a cualquier desarrolladora, sin importar el lenguaje del que vengas.

speaker: Erik Hooijmeijer
title: Zoetermeer Tech Night
subject: Presentatie 'Decompiling Kotlin
description:
While my colleagues revelled in Kotlin’s new features, I was curious how exactly these features are achieved on the JVM. So I spent some time reading byte code and decompiling Kotlin into Java with sometimes hilarious results.

In this presentation a take some example code in Kotlin, compile it and then decompile it with a Java decompiler and explain the results. Sometimes the decompiler produces really ..interesting.. code and then we take a deep dive into bytecode land to see what is going on – don’t worry I will explain what you need to know!

If you want to know how Kotlin achieves its ‘magic’ named arguments or how package level methods are built on the JVM this is the talk for you

speaker: Alexander Kotsyuruba
title: Kotlin Moscow
subject: Растопим синтаксический сахар Kotlin в виртуальной машине Java
description: Тема компиляции Kotlin в байткод JVM будет интересна разработчикам, пишущим на Java и желающим ознакомиться с Kotlin, а также разработчикам Kotlin, которые хотят больше погрузиться в специфику языка.

speaker: Vyacheslav Artemyev
title: Kotlin Moscow
subject: Корутины на практике: асинхронный клиент для RabbitMQ
description: В рамках доклада будут представлены концепции coroutines в Kotlin и применены на практике полученные знания для написания асинхронного клиента RabbitMQ. По итогу рассмотрим перфоманс тесты библиотеки, которая оказалась быстрее библиотеки Reactor Rabbit by Spring* * - на кейсах отправки до 1000 сообщений за раз

speaker: Gennady Vasilkov
title: Kotlin Moscow
subject: Теория и практика разработки на Kotlin Multiplatform
description: В этом докладе поговорим о возможностях переиспользования кода при мультиплатформенной разработке Android-, iOS- и Backend- приложений на Kotlin. Расскажем об опыте внедрения в существующий проект и чем мы поделились с бекенд командой. И в конце сравним Kotlin Multiplatform с нативной разработкой, поговорим о проблемах в реализации на платформах.

speaker: Lee Turner
title: Brighton Kotlin
subject: Kotlin Multiplatform at HMRC
description: During this talk, he will talk about the reasons behind the use of KMP and how he made it work with iOS, Android and Web. Come along to find out whether KMP could be used in your projects or maybe just to pique your interest into the world of KMP!

speaker: Haim Michael
title: life michael tel aviv
subject: The Power of Coroutines in Kotlin
description: This meetup was created for people with basic knowledge in Kotlin.

speaker: Biswa Phuyal
title: Washington DC Kotlin User Group
subject: Kotlin beyond the basics
description: As Kotlin is the preferred language for Android, I will share about very basic syntax to more advanced uses for functions, class scenarios, and delegation including best practices for working with generics, asynchronous programming etc. Understand the approach that makes Kotlin so extensible and unique compared to other JVM languages. After this session you will have a good base to start building or enhancing some serious Kotlin based app.

speaker: Nick DiPatri
title: GDG Philadelphia
subject: Coroutines
description: Nick will lead a live coding presentation of Kotlin coroutines.

speaker: Ryan Simon
title: OC Kotlin Krew
subject: Practical Kotlin Workshop: Coroutines and Flows
description: I'd like to say our workshops are for everyone, but it helps to have the following: - Previous experience with programming in any language - Looking to learn new languages - Want to learn about new and existing Kotlin concepts - A desire to join a community of passionate Kotlin engineers

speaker: Viktor Penelski
title: REWE Digital Bulgaria
subject: Kotlin for Java developers
description: The talk will be on an introductory level, showcasing some of the language features from the standpoint of a Java developer.

speaker: Neil Gall
title: Edinburgh Kotlin User Group
subject: Parser Combinators in Kotlin
description: How to write maintainable string parsing code. Neils interesting presentation style which went down well at EuroPython 2018 is to introduce a subject while live coding.

speaker: Stephan Oudmaijer
title: Sourcelabs B.V.
subject: Parser Combinators in Kotlin
description: Getting familiar with: - Kotlin language basics - Classes and Objects - Functions and Lambdas - Collections

speaker: Laurence Willmore
title: Kotlin Johannesburg
subject: Pure Kotlin web server with Ktor
description: GA demo of how to build a pure kotlin website and web server with the Ktor framework. This will be async/non-blocking, and we will see if we can pull in an introduction to some other kotlin libraries for things such as dependency injection and DB interaction.

speaker: Ankush Gupta
title: San Francisco Kotlin Meetup
subject: Multiplatform Kotlin
description: Ankush Gupta will be teaching us how Quizlet uses Kotlin Multiplatform to power learning experiences for over 50 million monthly active users. He'll share Quizlet's journey getting Kotlin Multiplatform into production, how it stacks up against their previous approach, and (most importantly) lessons they learned along the way.

speaker: Mark Ducommun
title: Chicago Kotlin Users Group
subject: Neural Networking w/ Kotlin Metaprogramming: A Cheaper Alternative to AI
description: A Cheaper Alternative for Deep Learning? - this talk is a continuation of the 2018 KotlinConf talk from Kotlin: The Next Frontier in Modern (Meta)programming. The talk highlights TornadoFX-Suite, which is a program that analyzes other TornadoFX projects and generates simple UI tests. In order to create smarter testing, we take a look at an new theory coming out of this project - how metaprogramming creates neural networking in comparison to neural networking in AI, and how neural networking in metaprogramming may provide a lot less processing power and more interesting results. I’m currently working with this theory right now to prove it, and I’m interested in sharing the results when I have it.

speaker: Murat Yener, Nicole Borrelli, Wenbo Zhu
title: Android Dev Summit 2019
subject: Java❤️ Kotlin, Happy Together 🎵
description:
Kotlin is awesome and you want to write all your code in it, but what about the thousands of lines of code already written in the Java programming language? Or, maybe you have a library or project that is written in Java and already has been used in so many Kotlin or Java projects.

In this talk, we will look at the best practices for writing Kotlin and Java code that works so seamlessly from the other that the only way to what language it is written in is to look at the source code.

speaker: Jose Alcérreca, Yigit Boyar
title: Android Dev Summit 2019
subject: LiveData with Coroutines and Flow
description: LiveData is a simple lifecycle-aware observable, designed for making UIs that react to changes safely and efficiently. It can be used beyond View↔️ViewModel communications and even components like Room support it. However, there's a risk of overuse, especially when dealing with multiple threads. The solution? Instead of expanding its features, LiveData now works seamlessly with Kotlin's coroutines. In this talk, we cover the new "liveData" coroutine builder, showing when and how to use it and testing patterns and antipatterns to make clean, efficient, and solid reactive UIs.

speaker: John Kolo, Shola Akinrolie
title: Kotlin Minna User Group, Nigeria
subject: Kotlin Night Minna
description: We will discuss it's introduction and how it functions with related technologies.

speaker: Paul Reilly
title: Kotlin Office Hours
subject: Deploying a fully covered, Kotlin DSL, Kotlin library
description: Deploying a library to Maven Central is not a big deal. What is a big deal is using the Gradle Kotlin DSL to accomplish this task for a 100% code covered Kotlin multi-platform library. Come hear more about using the Kotlin DSL, including buildSrc, 100% code coverage and interacting with the Maven Central site.

speaker: Victor Rentea
title: Bucharest Software Craftsmanship Community
subject: Kotlin Kindergarten ep #04 - Finally, some structured workflow
description:
Victor will broadcast 1 hour of live-coding playing around with Kotlin.

Expect a chaotic learning experience: completely unstructured, no beforehand preparation, just trying out things we find out googling around, right during the session. Victor does NOT know Kotlin. This is just the Playground of a Kotlin Kindergarten.

speaker: Victor Rentea
title: Bucharest Software Craftsmanship Community
subject: Kotlin Co-routines
description:
Victor will broadcast 1 hour of live-coding playing around with Kotlin.

Expect a chaotic learning experience: completely unstructured, no beforehand preparation, just trying out things we find out googling around, right during the session. Victor does NOT know Kotlin. This is just the Playground of a Kotlin Kindergarten.

speaker: Tom Cambell
title: Android Manchester
subject: Kotlin Co-routines
description: Tom Cambell from JLR will be sharing his experiences about Kotlin co-routines & beyond

speaker: Todd Ginsberg
title: Kansas City Java Users Group
subject: Kotlin with Todd Ginsberg
description:
Kotlin sure has been receiving a lot of buzz lately, is there something to it? Developed by JetBrains, Kotlin has been catching on lately because of its null safety guarantees, functional nature, type inference, full interoperability with Java, cross-platform support, and ease of use with Android and Spring. Is this something you and your team should considering spending time to learn?

One of the most interesting aspects of Kotlin is its design philosophy. Bugs that exist in Java such as NullPointerExceptions are not possible in Kotlin. This mentality of preventing common bugs at the language level exists all through the Kotlin syntax and standard library. Kotlin is also far less verbose than Java, reducing the amount of code you need to read in order to understand it. It also runs on JVMs down to Java 6, without sacrificing features. So if you are in a constrained environment such as Android or an enterprise shop struggling to upgrade, Kotlin might be worth considering.

In this talk, you will learn where Kotlin came from, what its major features are, and why people are using it more and more. At the end of the talk, you will be in a position to make an educated decision about whether Kotlin is right for you!

speaker: Marty Pitt
title: JVM Roundabout
subject: Building Microservices that connect and adapt themselves with Spring Boot, Kotlin and Vyne
description: Who will show us how to leverage TypeAliases in Kotlin to build a rich DSL, and then how to leverage these TypeAliases to build Microservices that automatically integrate themselves, and evolve as APIs change.

speaker: David Denton
title: JVM Roundabout
subject: Server as a Function in Kotlin
description: This talk is about a particular project and Springer Nature and covers how the team migrated the stack to Continuous Delivery-based deployment into a private on-premise cloud, and how http4k helped them introduce new failure-mode and inter-service contract testing techniques. This approach combines functional programming concepts and the versatility of Kotlin to produce applications that are simpler and more testable than most Java are accustomed to experience. And the best of it: with absolutely no magic!

speaker: Chet Haase
title: GDG Kraków
subject: Kotlin Under the Hood: Understand the Internals
description:
Kotlin offers great, modern language features and a rich set of extensions. But it's not always obvious to the developer what's happening under the hood. This session will help you understand better what these features and extensions are doing internally. It will also show how you can use the tools that Android offers to find this kind of information on your own.

After that we will have short break for networking. During second session Wojtek will tell us about Kotlin Multiplatform. Candy!

speaker: Wojtek Kalicinski
title: GDG Kraków
subject: Kotlin Multiplatform: code sharing without compromise
description: The promise of cross-platform frameworks looks great on paper, and some of them do a pretty good job delivering actual results. But with inherent differences between platforms, is "build once, run anywhere" even worth pursuing? Learn how you can share parts of your app between mobile platforms (and even the web!) without compromising quality, and delivering a best in class Android experience. During this talk I'll explain some ideas on how to structure not only your code, but also your teams, I'll show how to implement your own Kotlin MP libraries and showcase a few ones that you can use out-of-the-box.

speaker: Thomas Nield
title: Kotlin Night Chicago
subject: The Many Types of "AI"
description: As programmers, we love solving problems. However, sometimes we need more than programmer grit to solve many problems with no easy answer. Suppose you need to tightly schedule 190 classes in 20 classrooms, with different class durations, recurrences, and constraints throughout the week? What about minimizing the operating cost of a train schedule while maintaining a steady movement of passengers? How about identifying objects in images? Or simply solving a Sudoku?

speaker: Victoria Gonda
title: Kotlin Night Chicago
subject: Transforming your Tests with Kotlin
description: We know we should write tests, and we know that Kotlin gives us some nice features to use in our code, so how can we put these two together? There are some really great ways that Kotlin is being used in test writing, and we'll look at a number of them. This will include features such as higher order functions and escaping back-ticks and how they can make your tests more expressive. We'll also look at some testing libraries that take advantage of Kotlin's features. At the end of this talk you'll walk away with an understanding of how you can use Kotlin to make your tests more enjoyable.

speaker: Bartłomiej Szczepanik
title: Kraków Kotlin User Group
subject: Kotlin from backend developer perspective
description: 8 months ago my team decided to select Kotlin as our language of choice for our backend services. Since then we write new code only in Kotlin and slowly migrate our existing codebase. I'd like to share experiences we gathered so far: good and bad parts of the migration, gotchas and Java/Kotlin compatibility issues

speaker: Dan Lowe
title: Mapbox User Group | DC
subject: Kotlin: A Practical Introduction
description: Kotlin allows developers to accomplish more with less code, making code more maintainable by being safer, easier to read, and easier to test. The spotlight often seems to be mostly on Android, where over 50% of developers are currently using it in their projects, but use of Kotlin is growing in a range of other applications as well. Kotlin's ability to interoperate with Java, compile natively on most architectures, and even transpile into Javascript mean this relatively new language has a lot of still unrealized potential.

speaker: Tomas Hanley
title: Kotlin Belfast User Group
subject: Kotlin Coroutines - Case Study and Lessons Learned
description:
Asynchronous code can get really messy, really quickly. There are some good ways to avoid this in your design, but sometimes you have to live with some ugly old async API. Maybe because it's provided by a third party, or maybe it's just too difficult to rip out and rewrite. What you can do in this case is to write a Kotlin extension/wrapper on top of the API.

Kotlin Coroutines are a fantastic way to clean up ugly async APIs. They can make your async code as easy to read and understand as sequential code, but give you all the benefits of non blocking async code. In this session Tomas will be sharing with us how he took an ugly asynchronous API and wrote a Kotlin extension on top of it using coroutines and channels to make it super clean and easy to use. He'll also be sharing some of the lessons and best practices he learned along the way.

speaker: Chris Barbour, Garth Gilmour
title: Kotlin Belfast User Group
subject: DSLs and CloudFormation with a 'K'
description: In this talk, Garth and Chris will show you how to build your own DSLs in Kotlin, presenting the basic building blocks as supported by the language. You will then see how Chris's company, HexLabs, created a DSL to underpin their KloudFormation open source project - a type safe language for defining AWS CloudFormation Templates, making the automation of AWS infrastructure a much better experience.

speaker: Anton Kosiak
title: GDG Lviv
subject: Kotlin - two birds with one stone.

speaker: Aviv Vegh
title: KotlinTLV
subject: SDK and kotlin
description: In the session Aviv Vegh will talk about SDK development: issues which occurred during development, how his team solved them and how they added kotlin their project.

speaker: Cristian Benedit
title: ThoughtWorks Stuttgart
subject: Less is more: transitioning from Java to Kotlin
description: Kotlin has several advantages over Java. Is this true? And if so, what are the advantages and how can my team benefit from them? We plan to cover all the cool, and not so cool stuff involved in moving from Java to Kotlin. The syntax, the learning curve, the possibility of living with both, at least for some time, the tools and when does it make sense to start with the transition

speaker: Mario Fernandez
title: ThoughtWorks Stuttgart
subject: What we learnt building a microservice in Kotlin
description: Kotlin promises to be a concise and safe language with an easy transition from Java. We wanted to see how that looked in practice, so we wrote our latest microservice in it. I want to talk about how that worked for us and what we learnt on the way (SPOILER: we like it a lot)

speaker: Boris Strandjev
title: Hopper Tech Talks
subject: Android functional testing made easy with Kotlin
description: Boris chose the Android side of mobile dev seven years ago. He has been part of the development of dozens of applications and has also architected Android automation test framework that was later open-sourced. Now is part of the team of multi-million Hopper flight booking app where is reviving his test automation knowledge and putting it in good use. Many of you have already seen him in the numerous conferences/sessions he has lead. Feel invited to enjoy another evening together.

speaker: Ash Davies, Sinan Kozlak
title: droidconBETA - monthly meetup
subject: Working with Kotlin & Dagger
description:
Dagger has become one of the most widely used libraries in Android development, and is often one of the first to be thought of when bootstrapping a new project, but there are still many nuances and caveats that often get overlooked!

Many questions arose after the adoption of Kotlin, on how to continue following best practices from Java, so whether you’re using dagger-android or vanilla Dagger, Ash and Sinan will explain how to ensure a smooth module interplay and go through some tips and tricks to make sure you’re using Dagger to it’s best capacity.

speaker: Rick Busarow
title: Chicago Kotlin Users Group
subject: Coroutine-first Android architecture
description:
Coroutines are the new hot stuff, and right now they’re being added to lots of libraries. But what if you don’t want to use an alpha01 in production code? What can coroutines do on their own, right now?

In this talk, we’ll discuss the power behind structured concurrency and how we can use it to make our entire stack lifecycle-aware. We’ll look at examples of how to turn any callback or long-running code into a coroutine, and we’ll go over when and how to use Channels to handle hot streams of data without leaking. Finally, and most importantly, we’ll see how we can use these tools to inform our application architecture, so that we can quickly write maintainable and testable features.

speaker: Salman Nazir
title: techcamp Hamburg
subject: Why you should choose Kotlin for Native Android Development
description: Kotlin is a great programming language from JetBrains, the maker of the world's best IDEs. In this presentation, I would try to show you the biggest advantages (in my opinion) of a great programming language – Kotlin for Android development. While comparing it with previous Android language (JAVA) I will demonstrate (with Code Snippets) how Kotlin is plus in readability, having elegant solutions of Java's biggest issues, and the vast amount of features that we won't see in Java anytime soon and many more. In short, we will have the whole picture of Kotlin starting from its History till Kotin in the future.

speaker: Sean Massie
title: Kotlin Portland User Group
subject: Kotlin, standing on the shoulders of Giants
description: This talk will be a discussion on the wonders of Java and what Kotlin has done to build on them.

speaker: Noe Luaces
title: XConf Europe 2019
subject: Kotlin and Arrow: the functional way

speaker: Pavel Pristalov
title: GDG Penza
subject: Kotlin Multiplatform & Kotlin/Native
description: Павел Присталов расскажет о том, как писать кросплатформенный код на Kotlin и покажет пример игры с единым движком, используемым в нативных приложениях для Android и iOS.

speaker: Mario Müller
title: Web Engineering Düsseldorf
subject: Writing Stream Processors in Kotlin
description:
Kotlin skyrocket'ed in the past year and especially since Google adopted it as first-class citizen on the Android platform. But Kotlin does not only rock the mobile scene, it also takes the server side development in a storm. I will talk about home automation, Kafka and it's related frameworks and why I think Kotlin is the superior choice for writing Stream Processors.

This talk gives a short and basic introduction into Kafka and Kafka Streams in on a conceptual level, in order to enable the audience without any Kafka experience to follow along.

speaker: Mariano Zorrilla
title: Android Devs Buenos Aires
subject: Cambiando la co-routina con Kotlin
description: KEl paso evolutivo desde AsyncTask, pasando por RxJava hasta llegar a Coroutines y su filosofia

speaker: Cedric Ravalec
title: Kotlin Paris Meetup
subject: Kotlin, Flutter & PWA
description: Present the technology they're invested into, and why. You'll be able to understand, in under an hour, what are these techs, how they work, and why are they popular.

speaker: Sergey Melekhin
title: GDG Vladivostok
subject: Kotlin/Everywhere Vladivostok
description: Откроем для себя Kotlin, язык, созданный JetBrains для платформы JVM и стремительно набирающий популярность.

speaker: Adrien Pessu
title: Lava JUG
subject: Kotlin: Le back du futur, le codelab
description: Depuis l’annonce par Google du support de Kotlin sur Android, les développeurs d’applications mobiles se sont fortement intéressés à ce langage récent. Mais “Nom de Zeus !” est-ce réservé aux développeurs mobiles ? Non, Non et Non. Kotlin tourne sur la jvm alors autant en profiter dans tous nos projets. Viens découvrir toutes les facettes de ton futur prochain langage préféré. Au travers de cette conférence je te présenterai les principaux avantages du langage. Que ce soit les data class, les extensions, les coroutines… Je profiterai également d’un bout de code pour te montrer qu’il est simple de faire une API avec Spring et Kotlin. On apprendra à transformer ton vieux Java en Kotlin puis à penser directement en Kotlin pour plus de “fun” et moins de “void”.

speaker: Venkat Subramaniam
title: The Colorado Springs Open Source Software Meetup Group
subject: Kotlin for Java Programmers
description: There's so much you know as a Java programmer and yet there is so much more that Kotlin offers. It's a language that is built on strong foundations and, at the same time, brings along phenomenal concepts to favor low ceremony, fluency, sensible warnings, safe types, pragmatic mixture of object-oriented and functional programming, and so much more. In this presentation, you'll start with what you already are familiar with, and dive into Kotlin, to learn about its strengths and capabilities.

speaker: Sam Edwards
title: Richmond Java Users Group
subject: DIY Dependency Injection with Kotlin
description: Dependency Injection seems like this SUPER complex topic that only the most senior developers understand. At the end of the day, it's just "inversion of control" where instances of objects/classes are provided to you, instead of created by you. Kotlin's language features allow us to do this concisely, without a library, and in this talk I'll show you how to DO IT YOURSELF. This talk will demystify dependency injection and help you understand the huge benefits it provides for testing, maintainability and modularity.

speaker: Vipul Shah
title: droidcon Berlin 2019
subject: Kotlin/Native and Multiplatform Development
description: This workshop will introduced you to Kotlin/Native and build a Kotlin Multiplatform app that runs on both iOS and Android using shared Kotlin code. We will cover following topics in this workshop

speaker: Ragunath Jawahar
title: droidcon Berlin 2019
subject: Jetpack Compose — Next Gen Kotlin UI Toolkit for Android
description:
Reactive applications are the norm on the web. Android applications have begun increasingly reactive using architectures like MVVM, MVI, Redux, etc., The reactive nature of these applications are due to the underlying architecture rather than the UI framework itself. This has resulted in some big wins like testability and strong separation of concerns while trading-off attributes like time-to-market and quickly on-boarding new developers to an existing project.

The API surface of the Android UI framework has been the same for the past decade. This was largely because of the limitations imposed by old tooling and the programming language. With Kotlin bringing in DSLs, functional programming and compiler plugin capabilities - the members of the Android UI Toolkit team have rolled up their sleeves and are taking a new direction. The new UI toolkit is backed by principles and techniques like - one-way data flow, function composition, declarative programming, optimistic concurrency control, isolation of side-effects, etc.,

This shift in API design also demands a shift in thinking about the app architecture and building UIs. In this talk, we’ll see how Jetpack Compose is radically different from the existing Android UI framework and how it adopts several ideas and programming patterns from web frameworks like React, MobX, and Vue.js. We will also see examples of these patterns and use them to build Android apps.

speaker: Filip Babić
title: droidcon Berlin 2019
subject: Deep diving into the Kotlin Coroutines API
description:
Have you been learning Kotlin Coroutines by trial and error? Do you need a change of pace and environment or just a guide which doesn't baffle you with the sheer amounts of computer science terms, which coroutines are built upon?

Look no more! In this session, we'll go over the majority of the Kotlin Coroutines API, with the emphasis on explaining how each component works, which principles and elements are used behind the scenes, and how you can utilize Coroutines in your code, without burning out due to all the theory that is the foundation of computing and multi-threading.

speaker: Jossi Wolf
title: droidcon Berlin 2019
subject: Building SDKs - The Kotlin Way
description:
Building SDKs can be a challenging task: finding the right architecture, designing APIs that natural to use, keeping your code clean and finding ways to change APIs with grace after you decided to rewrite them once again.

Starting with common pitfalls while building SDKs, you will learn useful tricks and how you can use Kotlins features to create and maintain a stable API, for example, the @Deprecated and @Experimental annotation, typealiases and class delegation. Moving on, you will get to know about finding the right balance between generalisation and customisation, magic tricks for initialisation and publishing your SDK to a private Maven repository.

You will leave this talk ready to build shiny, stable and testable SDKs that are a breeze to be used. Moreover, you will also know about the right way for you to distribute your SDK to the next billion developers.

speaker: Marcin Moskała
title: droidcon Berlin 2019
subject: Kotlin Not-to-Do List - What we should avoid doing in Kotlin
description: Kotlin gives us a lot of possibilities, but with every power comes responsibility. What should we avoid doing in Kotlin? What are Kotlin internal contracts in terms of different features and functions? What is dangerous and should be avoided? How to code responsively?

speaker: Ankush Gupta
title: droidcon Berlin 2019
subject: A Journey in Shared Code with Kotlin Multiplatform
description:
Hear the story of how we shipped Kotlin Multiplatform across Android, iOS, and the Web to power Quizlet’s learning experience for over 50 million users per month. By pinpointing the best areas of our already mature codebase to share (and intentionally skipping over many others), Quizlet was able to use Kotlin Multiplatform to share the “secret sauce” of our product without shackling our Android, iOS, and Web clients to a predetermined architecture.

HWe drastically reduced the size of our Android app, achieved performance and stability wins across both iOS and Android, simplified our Web build process, and unlocked the ability for mobile and backend engineers to work confidently on this shared code -- but we also faced several speed bumps along the way. Learn how we overcame challenges such as platform-specific quirks of the Kotlin standard library, constantly evolving tooling, and many more to make the magic happen!

speaker: Evgeny Petrenko
title: St. Petersburg Kotlin User Group
subject: Kotlin: Нейтив код с удовольствием
description:
Насколько сложно для Java программиста написать программу, которая работает без виртуальной машины на голом железе? Не нужно бояться! Мы поговорим, как можно это осуществить, даже без виртуальной машины, но с комфортом, к которому мы привыкли с Java. Мы напишем нативный код на Kotlin, современном языке с открытым исходным кодом и статической типизацией, который поддерживает много платформ, включая iOS, Android, JVM, JS, linux, macOS, windows и многие другие.

Чтобы было еще интереснее, мы используем в нашей программе на Kotlin библиотеки написанные на С и Objective-C/Swift. Кстати, наш код можно сделать доступным и для этих языков. Напоследок, мы поговорим, как можно написать код на Котлине один раз и скомпилировать его для всех платформ сразу, используя Kotlin Multiplatform projects.

speaker: Leonid Startsev
title: St. Petersburg Kotlin User Group
subject: Дизайн kotlinx.serialization
description: Библиотека kotlinx.serialization поддерживает сериализацию без рефлексии котлиновских классов в различные форматы на JVM, JS и Native. Если вы хоть раз задумывались, как именно эта магия работает изнутри и почему библиотека получилась такой, как она выглядит, этот рассказ для вас. Сначала мы рассмотрим основные пользовательские юзкейсы и как библиотека помогает их решать. Затем мы взглянем на более низкоуровневые интерфейсы и поймём, зачем нужен плагин к компилятору. И в конце, посмотрим как можно легко расширить библиотеку написанием своего простого формата сериализации.

speaker: Phil Shadlyn
title: GDG Toronto Android
subject: What is Kotlin Serialization, and should I use it?

speaker: Tobse Fritz
title: Java User Group Karlsruhe
subject: Kotlin 1.3 in Action und Kotlin Multiplatform & Kotlin Native in Action
description:
Kotlin hilft uns, mit unseren bekannten Tools Software besser zu entwickeln, die im Code prägnant ist und weniger Fehler enthält. An vielen Stellen versucht es Designfehler von Java auszumerzen und bringt neue Programmiermodelle mit, die uns unterstützen Probleme mit neuem Handwerkszeug zu meistern. Dabei ist Kotlin dafür ausgelegt, sich nahtlos in bestehende Java-Projekte zu integrieren und selbst auf älteren 1.6 JVMs zu laufen. Ob Delegations, Reified Types... wir werden uns anschauen, welche Kotlin Features ein Java Entwickler kennen sollte und wie sie uns weiterhelfen. Dabei nehmen wir auch das neuste Kotlin 1.3 Update mit Coroutinen und Inline Classes unter die Lupe. Der Vortrag richtet sich sowohl an Kotlin-Neueinsteiger, als auch an Fortgeschrittene, die sich für die Neuerungen im Update 1.3 interessieren.

Kotlin ist weitaus mehr als eine Sprache auf der JVM. Mit Kotlin Native und Kotlin Multiplatform eröffnen sich völlig neue Möglichkeiten für eine plattformübergreifende Entwicklung. Ob im Backend, im Browser, auf Smartphones oder selbst auf Embedded Systemen, überall lässt sich in Kotlin programmieren, Code wiederverwenden und selbst ohne JVM nativ ausführen. Wie wäre es mit nativen IOs Apps, schlanken Microservices ohne JVM, oder Backends die sich mit dem Frontend die Codebase teilen? Wie setze ich ein solches Multiplatform Projekt auf? Wie kann ich nativ entwickeln und wo sind noch die Vor- und Nachteile - auch im Vergleich mit GraalVM?

speaker: Anton Spaans
title: Kotlin Office Hours
subject: Asynchrony in Kotlin, Rx vs Coroutines
description: This talk will give you an overview of both Rx and Coroutines, which allow you to deal with asynchronous programming, and provide a short participatory checklist to determine which of the 2 solutions would work best (for your particular app).

speaker: João Carvalho
title: Kotlin Lisboa
subject: Kofu: Functional Spring Configuration
description: Spring Kofu (for Kotlin and functional) is an experimental new API for configuring Spring applications. Instead of relying on annotations and classpath scanning to configure your application, Kofu provides you an explicit Kotlin DSL for functional bean definition. Combined with the GraalVM, Kofu applications start in just a few milliseconds and have a lower memory footprint.

speaker: Bruno Félix
title: Kotlin Lisboa
subject: Testing with Kotlin: patterns and practices from the trenches
description: In this talk we are going to do a deep dive on how we can leverage Kotlin's features to write readable and concise tests. We will focus on examples based in real-life projects, covering a broad range of topics including: tooling, useful libraries, patterns for writing readable tests, and integration testing with framewoks like ktor and test containers.

speaker: Chris Werner Rau
title: Bielefelder Kotlin User Group
subject: Kotlin Intro
description:
Ein kleines Kotlin Intro. Was ist Kotlin, warum Kotlin und Unterschiede zu Java.

Nicht sehr tiefgehend, gerade genug um den nachfolgenden Talk zu verstehen.

speaker: Roland Ryan
title: GDG Madison
subject: An Introduction to Kotlin for Android Developers
description: If you're a skilled Java/Android developer, learning the basics of Kotlin is already extremely easy by just jumping into it on your own. In this talk, Roland Ryan will not be going over the all of the basics, but instead will be walking through a few of the things he wishes he knew about Kotlin before diving into it himself.

speaker: Venkat Subramaniam
title: ÜberConf X
subject: Programming with Kotlin
description:
Kotlin is one of those few multi-platform languages. You can compile Kotlin to Java bytecode, to Android, to WebAssembly, to run native on different OS, and to JavaScript. The language draws inspiration from many different languages. It is highly fluent and code in Kotlin is concise, elegant, and easy to maintain. This workshop will get you up to speed on using Kotlin for your day-to-day programming.

The workshop will start with the language basics and quickly dive into some of the more advanced features. We will also look at ways to use compile time metaprogramming and create fluent DSLs.

speaker: Kenneth Kousen
title: ÜberConf X
subject: Kotlin Fundamentals
description:
Learn the basic syntax and semantics for the Kotlin programming language. Kotlin is an alternative JVM language that provides null safety, static typing, and powerful IDE support. This talk will emphasize the relationships between Kotlin and Java, highlighting the differences in types, functional programming, collections, and more.

Demonstrations will include:

how to transform Kotlin code to view the equivalent Java how to work with classes, interfaces, and objects how to use collections, streams, and sequences and much more.

speaker: Kenneth Kousen
title: ÜberConf X
subject: Gradle For And In Kotlin
description:
The release of Gradle 5.0 includes the official 1.0 version of the Gradle Kotlin DSL. The Kotlin DSL brings strong typing, null safety, and, most importantly, powerful IDE support to Gradle. The goal is to improve the user experience with Gradle build files through code assist and improved readability. This presentation will demonstrate the new build style, both for Java projects and for Kotlin projects.

The talk will include recommendations on how to move from the Groovy DSL to Kotlin, how to navigate and use the Kotlin DSL samples in the documentation, how to define tasks, use plugins, and more.

speaker: Kenneth Kousen
title: ÜberConf X
subject: Kotlin: Beyond the Basics
description:
This talk will examine features of Kotlin at a greater depth than most tutorials. Higher order functions will be covered, as well as reduction operations like reduce and fold, and lambdas with receivers. Those topics progress toward building DSLs and builders in Kotlin. Terms like “apply”, “let”, “use”, “also”, and “with” will be covered along with their typical use cases. Finally, and introduction to Kotlin coroutines will be included.

Details of the type system, including the Any, Unit, and Nothing classes, will be included. Examples will be provided on how to define extension functions, infix operators, and inlining functions for efficiency.

speaker: Antonio Arista Jalife
title: Academia de tecnología y programación México (BEDU)
subject: Introducción a Kotlin
description: Kotlin es considerado por Google como uno de los lenguajes oficiales para desarrollar para Android, es muy fácil de aprender y tiene alta demanda en el mercado.

speaker: Bas Cancrinus
title: Kotlin user group Berlin
subject: Informal get-together of Kotlin developers in Berlin

speaker: Antonio Arista Jalife
title: Academia de tecnología y programación México (BEDU)
subject: Introducción a Kotlin
description: Kotlin es considerado por Google como uno de los lenguajes oficiales para desarrollar para Android, es muy fácil de aprender y tiene alta demanda en el mercado.

speaker: Christoph Engelbert
title: Kotlin User Group Düsseldorf
subject: Using Spring as an API gateway
description: Spring has gotten seriously fast – fast enough to be used as a super-flexible, programmable reverse proxy in front a bunch of backend services that average thousands of requests per second. Let's take a look at why you might want to do that, how many lines of Kotlin we need to do it… and when you might be better off sticking to established solutions like nginx or HAProxy.

speaker: Aleks Haecky
title: Summer Kotlin Study Group
subject: Kotlin Bootcamp for Programmers by Google
description: Learn the essentials of the Kotlin programming language from Kotlin experts at Google. Kotlin is a modern and concise JVM language that supports functional programming paradigms. Whether you’re a Java developer or a programmer in another object-oriented language, this course will teach you the essential language features that has made Kotlin so popular with developers. By the end of this course, you’ll gain the skills you need to build your next project in Kotlin.

speaker: Ciprian Popa
title: Visma TechTalks at Sibiu
subject: Kotlin - The New Prince in The Kingdom of Java (...and some other distant lands)
description: Kotlin started like a secret internal project at JetBrains (creators of Intellij IDEA family of very productive IDEs) that were unsatisfied with all the historically accumulated Java limitations. Then Kotlin was peaking some steam supporting Android development and suddenly everybody started to be interested into it, Now Google advertise Kotlin like the preferred programming language for Android. Other companies like Pivotal/Spring, Gradle, Pinterest, AirBnb, are considering it for backend, scripting and cross-platform (Android, iOS) capabilities due to Kotlin abilities to provide concise code, nice DSLs, powerful scripting features, amazing reactive and async support using coroutines and the most interesting one the JavaScript & Native compilers. If you are curious on why Kotlin might be the best investment into your programming tool belt, just join our talk.

speaker: Jonathan Bisson
title: GGDG Chicago
subject: Introduction to Kotlin: Kotlin Koans Workshop
description:
This tutorial walks you through a series of exercises to get familiar with Kotlin.

TKotlin Koans are a series of exercises to get you familiar with the Kotlin Syntax. Each exercise is created as a failing unit test and your job is to make it pass. You can work with Kotlin Koans in one of three ways.

speaker: Jan Stoltman
title: Mobile Warsaw
subject: Kotlin Multiplatform: what is it all about
description: As Kotlin gathers more and more popularity among the developers it sets out to solve one of the biggest problems of modern software development, per-platform business logic duplication. With Kotlin Multiplatform developing shared codebase for multiple platforms becomes easy and hassle free, but is this brave new technology worthwhile or is it just another hype wave? This presentation will explain what Kotlin Multiplatform is, how it works, what are its limitations and what differs it from its counterparts such as React Native or Flutter.

speaker: David Pavao
title: Kotlin South Florida Users Group
subject: Up and Running with Coroutines
description: We're back and its coroutine time! We're taking a look at getting started with Kotlin coroutines and how easy it can be to integrate into your existing projects. We'll cover its differences to existing callback based APIs. How you can bridge coroutines with existing async libraries. What some of the best practices are for embracing structured concurrency concepts. And explain what exactly is a "CoroutineContext". All experience levels are welcomed and we are looking to make this a very interactive event.

speaker: Walmyr Carvalho
title: Kotlin Meetup - São Paulo
subject: Não é feitiçaria, é Kotlin! Novidades da linguagem para profissionais Android

speaker: Rafael Toledo
title: Kotlin Meetup - São Paulo
subject: Kotlin: compartilhando código entre Android e iOS

speaker: Sergey Alekhin
title: Kotlin Moscow
subject: Про написание тестов на Kotlin для тестирования Java Backend

speaker: Chandra Sekhar Nayak
title: DevFest Kolkata 2019
subject: Sneaking inside Kotlin features
description:
Kotlin has many language features even though none of them are supported by JVM or Android ART. This talk will go through all the language features and understand how they work internally for JVM or ART compatibility.

Many developers in our community uses all these APIs without knowing how they work. After this talk, they will have a good understanding of how those features work.

speaker: Sam Edwards
title: Washington DC Kotlin User Group
subject: Select from Kotlin
description: Now that Kotlin is the preferred language of Android developers, what is the best library to work with SQLite databases using Kotlin? Room just released support for Kotlin Coroutines, and SqlDelight released support for Kotlin Multi-platform. Room has great documentation and hides a lot of implementation detail, while SqlDelight lets you write raw SQL statements with an Android Studio plugin and then generates type-safe code for you. In this session, you'll see a rundown of these two libraries, along with live coding demos to help you decide which library sounds right for you in this Kotlin world.

speaker: René Preißel
title: oose Events im Schanzenviertel
subject: Warum Entwickler Kotlin lieben
description: Im letzten Jahr gab es kaum eine Umfrage über beliebte Sprachen und Technologien in der Kotlin nicht auftauchte. Warum sind Java-Entwickler begeistert von der Sprache? Warum wurde das Spring-Framework um Kotlin-Features erweitert? Viele Entwickler schätzen die kompakte Syntax und die pragmatischen Lösungen von typischen Java-Schmerzpunkten. Innovative Features ermöglichen es, NullPointerException’s zu verbannen, vorhandene Klassen um Funktionen zu erweitern und mit verbesserten Lambdas eigene DSLs umzusetzen. Dieser Vortrag gibt einen kompakten Überblick über die Möglichkeiten der Sprache und diskutiert den Einstieg in die Entwicklung mit Kotlin.

speaker: Eury Perez
title: GDG Santo Domingo
subject: Kotlin From Zero To Hero
description:
Kotlin es un lenguaje moderno que utiliza el paradigma funcional creado por la empresa Jetbrains. Recientemente Google hizo el anuncio de que acogía a Kotlin como el lenguaje oficial de Android.

En esta charla podremos aprender los conceptos necesarios para comenzar a escribir código de calidad en lenguaje Kotlin.

speaker: Corneil du Plessis
title: I Code Java Conference 2019
subject: Converting from Java to Kotlin: Bring your own code
description: Have you wondered whether it is difficult to develop applications in Kotlin? Too scared to take the leap?During this workshop, we will explore techniques for converting from Java to Kotlin starting with some sample Spring Boot applications. The attendees are encouraged to bring along code that they are interested in converting from Java to Kotlin.Attendees should leave the workshop with some tools, techniques, and experience for a smooth conversion to Kotlin.Attendees should bring a laptop with their preferred Java development environment. We also suggest an installed JDK 8 and IntelliJ Community Edition or IntelliJ Ultimate Edition.

speaker: Riedwaan Bassadien
title: I Code Java Conference 2019
subject: Getting Started with Kotlin and AI on Kubernetes
description: Go from Zero to Kotlin on Kubernetes in a few minutes. If you know Zero or a little about Kubernetes this demo rich talk will get you exited and give you great tips on how to get started with the Kotlin on Kubernetes. See how you can seamlessly integrate AI into your projects.

speaker: Pamela Hill, Jacques Smuts
title: I Code Java Conference 2019
subject: Battle for the Droid: RxJava vs Kotlin Coroutines on Android
description: A fierce debate has been raging in the Android community as to whether it is better to use RxJava or Kotlin Coroutines. This talk will start by introducing the audience to the fundamental concepts of RxJava (Jacques) and Coroutines (Pamela), followed by a joint discussion on the use cases of each.

speaker: Renette Ros
title: I Code Java Conference 2019
subject: How I used Kotlin to develop a multiplatform game engine
description: Kotlin is popular for android apps and can be used to develop apps for the JVM. It is sometimes just considered a 'better java', but it can also be compiled to javascript or even native. In this talk I will talk about kotlin multi platform builds and take the audience through how we got the Entelect Challenge game engine running on the JVM and in a web browser.

speaker: Steven Ndaye
title: I Code Java Conference 2019
subject: From Effective Java to Effective Kotlin
description: There are a lot of Java idioms described in the book "Effective Java". This talk will go through some of the famous idioms and how they translate in Kotlin. These idioms can get pretty much verbose with Java, with this talk we will also see how Kotlin handles the verbosity.

speaker: Niel de Wet
title: I Code Java Conference 2019
subject: CQRS/ES with Kotlin and Axon
description: The open source Axon Framework is a mature JVM implementation of CQRS and Event Sourcing. Unfortunately this programming model is not very familiar to most South African Java developers. When I first started using it we did so in ignorance and learned our lessons the hard way. In this talk we will briefly discuss the key concepts of CQRS, Event Sourcing, Aggregates and Sagas. Then I will show a high level approach to implementing Axon properly and in support of a maintainable system.

speaker: Corneil du Plessis
title: I Code Java Conference 2019
subject: A Kotlin DSL for Finite-state machines – A Journey
description: Kotlin is an exciting language that makes it easy to build your own DSL. We will go on a journey of discovering the value of finite state machines and how you build your own DSL for simplifying configuration and use of an FSM. Developers should learn how to create their own DSLs as well as using this library to create FSMs in their own Kotlin projects regardless of platform.

speaker: Michael Pardo
title: droidconNYC 2019
subject: Multiplatform Functional Architecture
description: This session will demonstrate the power of Kotlin multiplatform and the Model-View-Update (MVU) architecture. Discover how to write a single, testable code base that runs on any platform.

speaker: Peter Pane
title: Kotlin Vienna
subject: Discussions about Kotlin and whatever else is on your mind

speaker: Paul Thompson
title: Sydney Kotlin User Group
subject: Make 100,000 unique HTTP requests fast with coroutines
description: Sometimes you need to perform many thousands of HTTP requests, to download files, interact with an API, or load test. In the past we at Canva were constantly creating Python or batch scripts to perform our tasks. Now we use a custom Kotlin DSL to make HTTP request scripting easy and ludicrously fast.

speaker: Jacob Bass
title: Sydney Kotlin User Group
subject: FP Answers to OO Questions
description: A tour through some functional design patterns, showcasing how to solve common object-oriented problems. Talk will demonstrate how they work, how to substitute them and what their trade-offs are.

speaker: Victor Rentea
title: Kotlin Kindergarten ep #06 - Kotlin Koans hands-on #3
subject:
Sick of Java? Let’s try Kotlin : probably the next de-facto standard for Android apps, and a cool
            compact language to write your JUnit tests in.
description: Expect a chaotic learning experience: completely unstructured, no beforehand preparation, just trying out things we find out googling around, right during the session.

speaker: Tommy Alsemgeest, Nic Tolentino
title: Auckland Android Community
subject: Jetpack Navigation and Kotlin stdlib extension functions
description: how to use it, what are SafeArgs, and how it differs from conventional navigation.

speaker: Mohit Sarveiya
title: New York Kotlin Meetup
subject: Channels & Flows
description: In this talk, Mo will present on how to use constructs such as actors, channels and flows in use cases. These use cases are modeling streams with channels and flows and using actors to ensure one concurrent job is running. Channels and Flows are experimental features that allow us to represent a stream of data. Flows represent a cold stream whereas a Channel is like a hot observable. We’ll dive into these topics.

speaker: Flavio Almeida
title: New York Kotlin Meetup
subject: Blockchain / Corda
description: An overview of a Decentralized Application written in Kotlin, from a perspective of architecture, code and deployment. Flavio will present the StreetWire real estate application built on Kotlin using R3's Corda open source platform deployed on Microsoft Azure, exploring the workings of the blockchain, Corda's framework, Kotlin code and technical aspects of the application. He also will share his experience as a participant of several Blockchain projects, most of them written in Corda, a blockchain platform that allows developers to code decentralized apps in Java or Kotlin.

speaker: Michal Harakal
title: Mobile Devs Darmstadt
subject: Mobile Entwicklung mit Kotlin Multiplatform
description:
Kotlin hat bereits die Android-Welt eingenommen und ich hatte viel Spaß dabei, für Android eine Open Source Konferenz-App in Kotlin zu schreiben. Den Prinzipien der Clean Code Architektur folgend, ist ein Großteil des Codes bereits Framework unabhängig. Ein Teil des Codes ist bereits Kotlin Multiplatform. Der nächste notwendige Schritt ist ein iOS Client.

Mit diesen Erfahrungen werden wir einen Blick auf Kotlin native und Kotlin Multiplatform werfen und versuchen dann eine einfache Cross-Plattform App von Grund auf zu schreiben. Ich verspreche euch, ich habe nur ein paar Folien und werde viel Live-Coden.

speaker: Sean McQuillan
title: Android Summit
subject: Performance in a Kotlin World
description: Users expect apps to be snappy, responsive, and jank-free. As developers, we want to use new language features and libraries. How do you make sure these new features deliver the performance users expect? In this talk, you’ll learn how to make your app shine with practical performance patterns. After this talk you’ll know how to use Android Studio profilers, new Jetpack Benchmarking library, and even strace to find and fix jank and keep it from coming back.

speaker: Sam Edwards
title: Android Summit
subject: DIY Dependency Injection with Kotlin
description: Dependency Injection seems like this SUPER complex topic that only the most senior developers understand. At the end of the day, it’s just “inversion of control” where instances of objects/classes are provided to you, instead of created by you. Kotlin’s language features allow us to do this concisely, without a library, and in this talk I’ll show you how to DO IT YOURSELF. This talk will demystify dependency injection and help you understand the huge benefits it provides for testing, maintainability and modularity.

speaker: Aida Issayeva
title: Android Summit
subject: Reactive Approach to Delegation in Kotlin
description: This talk will dive into Kotlin built-in support for property changes and implementation of custom view states by using it.

speaker: Russell Wolf
title: Android Summit
subject: Bottom-Up Code-Sharing with Kotlin Multiplatform
description: Kotlin Multiplatform enables sharing logic and architecture across platforms while still interacting with each platform’s native APIs. We’ll talk through what this looks like by walking through a sample application. We’ll highlight helpful patterns for both production and test code, as well as available tools and dependencies. Once we’re done you’ll be ready to leverage Kotlin’s code-sharing capabilities in your own projects, and never need to write the same logic twice ever again.

speaker: Ayelen Chavez
title: Droidcon
subject: Building Fast Prototypes for Fun and Profit (with Flutter + Kotlin/Native)
description: Flutter is a free and open source tool developed by Google to craft native mobile apps quickly using Dart as programming language. To make it even more fun (and faster) we used Kotlin/Native to implement the app's business model so both Android and iOS apps can use the same source code to model common behaviour.

speaker: Manuel Vivo
title: Droidcon
subject: Structured Concurrency: Asynchronous shift in Kotlin
description:
Before Kotlin Coroutines (async programming in Kotlin) was stable, they were launched in a way that made them difficult to maintain and track down.

Structured Concurrency introduced changes to solve these problems but also involved an ideological shift in order to use them.

In this talk, you'll learn how to do async programming in Kotlin using Structured Concurrency principles covering topics such as launching coroutines, scopes, error handling and testing.

speaker: Carlos Mota
title: Droidcon
subject: The Hitchhikers Guide Through Kotlin Multiplatform
description: Fast forward to the present, and now we have two new languages: Android is Kotlin first and iOS, Swift. And if you put them side by side you can see a lot of similarities between both what will ease switching between one to the other if you have to develop for both platforms.

speaker: Jeremy Rempel
title: Droidcon
subject: Building a Kotlin Native App on iOS and Android

speaker: David Gonzalez
title: Codemotion
subject: Building a library for Android and iOS using Kotlin Multiplatform
description: Sharing code between platforms is a powerful technique, but it may be hard to accomplish without rich APIs that we have in Android, JVM, or iOS platforms. Kotlin Multiplatform libraries can be used to fix that, bringing rich APIs directly in the common Kotlin code. What an exciting frontier! In this talk we'll go over the creation of a Kotlin Multiplatform library. You'll learn how modules for each platform work, decide what parts of the code makes sense to share and what doesn't. All based in the experiences gathered after creating a library at Mixtiles used to fetch images from different

speaker: Manuel Vicente Vivo
title: Codemotion
subject: Structured Concurrency: Asynchronous shift in Kotlin
description: Before Kotlin Coroutines (async programming in Kotlin) was stable, they were launched in a way that made them difficult to maintain and track down. Structured Concurrency introduced changes to solve these problems but also involved an ideological shift in order to use them. In this talk, you'll learn how to do async programming in Kotlin using Structured Concurrency principles covering topics such as launching coroutines, scopes, error handling and testing.

speaker: Eugene Petrenko
title: Codemotion
subject: Native with Kotlin/Native
description: Have you tried Native with Kotlin/Native? It compiles your Kotlin code for various native platforms, including iOS, Mac, Linux, and Windows. No virtual machine is needed! The native world brings native libraries, C static and dynamic libraries, Apple frameworks, Swift and Objective-C dependencies. Kotlin adds multiplatform libraries to share Kotlin code between different platforms. That is the way to share code between Android and iOS, between backend and frontend, between JVM, JavaScript, C, and Swift/Objective-C. Join us to learn about native development new Kotlin/Native

speaker: René Preißel
title: oose Events im Schanzenviertel
subject: Warum Entwickler Kotlin lieben
description: Im letzten Jahr gab es kaum eine Umfrage über beliebte Sprachen und Technologien in der Kotlin nicht auftauchte. Warum sind Java-Entwickler begeistert von der Sprache? Warum wurde das Spring-Framework um Kotlin-Features erweitert? Viele Entwickler schätzen die kompakte Syntax und die pragmatischen Lösungen von typischen Java-Schmerzpunkten. Innovative Features ermöglichen es, NullPointerException’s zu verbannen, vorhandene Klassen um Funktionen zu erweitern und mit verbesserten Lambdas eigene DSLs umzusetzen. Dieser Vortrag gibt einen kompakten Überblick über die Möglichkeiten der Sprache und diskutiert den Einstieg in die Entwicklung mit Kotlin.

speaker: André Ignacio
title: SouJava
subject: Renovando sua stack Spring com Kotlin
description: Nessa palestra será apresentada uma stack comum com Java, Spring Boot, Spring MVC e Spring Data, migraremos com live coding para Kotlin utilizando amplamente as features da linguagem e mostrando os principais problemas e como resolve-los.

speaker: Sascha Koch
title: Java User Group Bielefeld
subject: Enterprise Kotlin – Highway to Hell or Stairway to Heaven?
description:
Kotlin in einer Enterprise-Java-Anwendung? Kann das funktionieren? Wir berichten von unseren Erfahrungen bei der Einführung von Kotlin in einer langjährigen Java-Codebase. Was war unsere Motivation? Welche Vorteile haben wir uns zu Beginn versprochen? Und welche am Ende bekommen?

Wir veranschaulichen anhand von Beispielen konkrete Probleme und deren Lösungen. Die Teamdynamik und persönliche Befindlichkeiten werden auch eine Rolle spielen. Am Ende wird ein Fazit stehen, das hoffentlich anderen bei Entscheidungen helfen kann.

speaker: Andres Rubiano
title: Medellín Android
subject: Kotlin Co-Rutinas
description: Las co-rutinas son una nueva manera de manejar hilos en segundo plano que pueden simplificar el código al reducir los "callbacks". Las Co-Rutinas es una característica de Kotlin que convierte los "callbacks" como tareas de larga ejecución.

speaker: Andres Rubiano
title: Medellín Android
subject: Kotlin Co-Rutinas
description: Las co-rutinas son una nueva manera de manejar hilos en segundo plano que pueden simplificar el código al reducir los "callbacks". Las Co-Rutinas es una característica de Kotlin que convierte los "callbacks" como tareas de larga ejecución.

speaker: Jessica Lorena
title: Android Meetup Bogotá
subject: Programación reactiva en Android y Kotlin
description: En esta conferencia veremos un poco de programación reactiva en Kotlin y Android, donde aprenderemos a configurar RXKotlin en nuestros proyectos móviles, cómo crear observables, cómo suscribirnos y un poco de operadores de filtrado para realizar operaciones complejas.

speaker: Michal Harakal
title: Kotlin Meetup Rhein-Main
subject:
Kotlin Multiplatform roller-coaster ride - or how Android developer has written iOS conference App over
            a weekend

speaker: Marc Reichelt
title: Kotlin Meetup Rhein-Main
subject: Kotlin's companion object: The power of IntelliJ IDEA
description: Kotlin's power is coming not only by its syntax, but also by its awesome IDE integration. IntelliJ is full of great helpers and shortcuts that makes us more productive - and has some extras that make Kotlin development even better!

speaker: Arnab Datta
title: Oslo Kotlin Meetup
subject: GraphQL in Kotlin
description: We will start by introducing GraphQL: - A brief history of GraphQL - Advantages over traditional REST APIs

speaker: Sanjay Ramani
title: Kotlin Surat User Group
subject: Kotlin is Awesome
description: Kotlin is now one famous programming language for IT Industry. Its time to know the basic details of Kotlin. Agenda: How Kotlin is beneficial? How to start code with Kotlin? Less Code , More Fun

speaker: Sean McQuillan
title: droidconNYC 2019
subject: Performance in a Kotlin world
description: Users expect apps to be snappy, responsive, and jank-free. As developers, we want to use new language features and libraries. How do you make sure these new features deliver the performance users expect? In this talk, you'll learn how to make your app shine with practical performance patterns. After this talk you'll know how to use Android Studio profilers and the new Jetpack Benchmarking library to find and fix jank and keep it from coming back.

speaker: Jeremy Rempel
title: droidconNYC 2019
subject: Building apps using Kotlin Native
description: Pragmatic introduction to building iOS and Android apps utilizing Kotlin Native and related technologies. What, Why, How. Introductory/beginner talk to the technology appropriate for people familiar with Android/iOS development but not Kotlin Native technology. Target: All Engineering levels

speaker: Wojtek Kaliciński
title: droidconNYC 2019
subject: Android Jetpack ❤️ Kotlin: on the road to more wholesome APIs
description:
Two years ago, Android announced first-class support for the Kotlin programming language. Both the language and the platform evolved a lot during this time, with more focus from the engineering teams at Google on helping developers use the full power of Kotlin. In fact, we’ve seen tremendous adoption of the language among top Android app developers. That’s why, just 2 years later, we announced that, going forward, Android will become Kotlin-first.

In this talk I want to talk about the current state of Kotlin on Android, and give you a small glimpse into the future of what modern app development with Android Jetpack looks like.

speaker: Britt Barak
title: droidconNYC 2019
